awd_titl_txt: Conference: Re-imagining a cellular space occupied by condensates
awd_abstract_narration:
Condensates have emerged as a provocative new way to understand how cells are organized. This novel understanding suggests that the cell is occupied by numerous droplets, each comprised of a small number of member proteins that preferentially interact with each other. However, the available visual representations of condensates fail to communicate the growing body of knowledge about how condensates form and are maintained, and also focuses attention on only a subset of the potential implications of condensates. We therefore propose a workshop that will foster a community engaged with constructing a visual language and new tools to accurately capture the complexity of condensates. 

The workshop will bring together experts from diverse disciplines to re-imagine cellular space: about one-third of the participants will be biologists actively engaged in condensate research, one-third will be visualization and computation specialists, including modeling experts, data visualization specialists and molecular animators, and one-third will come from fields that do not normally engage with cell biology but that have long been thinking about space and ways to represent it, such as architecture, design, urbanism, and cognitive science. We will explore specific approaches to communicate concepts and intuitions about cellular space to colleagues and students. The representations created in the conference will generate experimentally-testable hypotheses and allow for the development of new tools for scientific communication and teaching.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Condensates have emerged as a provocative new way to understand how cells are organized. Rather than a dense and mostly disordered soup of macromolecules, this novel understanding suggests that the cell is occupied by numerous droplets, each comprised of a small number of member proteins that preferentially interact with each other. In the last decade, many condensates have been described, along with the specific interactions that regulate their formation and dispersion. Key tenets of modern cell biology are challenged by condensates. For example, the function and localization of many proteins have traditionally been defined by the identification of ?lock-and-key? interactions. In contrast, condensates underscore the importance of understanding labile and cooperative interfaces. The popularly held view of the cell as a densely-packed but dynamic space where proteins can diffuse largely unobstructed is also being challenged. The ubiquity of condensates suggests that diffusion in the cell should be thought of as travel on crowded thoroughfares that circumvent condensates. 

We hypothesize that our ability to conceptualize the nature and the implications of condensates is limited by the visual language and the technologies we use to represent cellular spaces. Condensates are frequently represented by colorful ovals suspended in empty space. This simplistic representation fails to communicate the growing body of knowledge about how condensates form and are maintained, and also focuses attention on only a subset of the potential implications of condensates. We therefore held a workshop that fostered a community engaged with constructing a visual language and new tools to accurately capture the complexity of condensates. Participants included experts from diverse disciplines to re-imagine cellular space: biologists actively engaged in condensate research, visualization and computation specialists, including modeling experts, data visualization specialists, and molecular animators, and representatives from other fields that do not normally engage with cell biology but that have long been thinking about space and ways to represent it, including architecture, and the history of science. 

Intellectual Merit

The workshop yielded new ways to represent cellular space and its many denizens, including condensates. Participants explored how graphical representations impact our thinking of cellular space, and the effect of modern lab techniques, which typically probe only a handful of proteins at a time, on our understanding of cellular organization. We discussed specific approaches to communicate concepts and intuitions about cellular space to colleagues and students, and talked about the development of new tools for scientific communication and teaching.

Broader Impact

The explosive interest in condensates in the last decade has already yielded many biological insights and research tools. However, lagging far behind are tools to communicate these findings to students and to the larger public. The products of this workshop will constitute the foundation of teaching materials and class modules to address this need. To disseminate the products of this workshop, we will publish a Perspective article and utilize social media. We have recruited diverse participants to our 3-day workshop, including junior researchers. For a public, one-day symposium held at the University of Utah campus we brought in students and instructors from a local community college.
